div.head: Title
div.p: In Poems (1891), W. G. Collingwood printed the title, Account of a Tour on the Continent, without square brackets, his symbol for declaring editorial intervention. Nonetheless, the title apparently originated with him, as Ruskin assigned no title to the sequence as a whole in any of the extant manuscripts (see Poems [4o, 1891], 1: 119, 281; Poems [8o, 1891], 1: 119, 282). What titles Ruskin supplied apply only to individual verse and prose sections of the work. Accordingly, in ERM, when the main title is fully spelled out, it is given without quotation marks, in keeping with the guidelines given in The System of Title Citation for Works. In this apparatus, however, for convenience in the course of discussion, a short title is used with quotation marks (i.e., the “Account”) in order to avoid confusion with surrounding text.

In another, more minor discrepancy respecting the editorial title, both Poems (1891) and the Library Edition cite the title in their respective tables of contents as “Account of a Tour on the Continent in 1833,” but the title pages of the work in these editions lack the extension containing the date (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:xv, 119; Poems [8o, 1891], 1:xix, 119; Ruskin, Works, 2:xii, 340).

Collingwood also invented titles for some individual sections of verse, untitled sections that he took from Ruskinʼs MS VIII draft of the “Account” in order to supplement the main copytext of poems taken from the MS IX fair copy. These editorial titles are as follows:
TO COME

When two selections from the “Account” were published in the literary annual, Friendshipʼs Offering (see Composition and Publication), the selections were subsumed together under the title, “Fragments from a Metrical Journal” (Friendshipʼs Offering; and Winterʼs Wreath . . . for MDCCCXXXV, 317–19). The responsibility for assigning this title is unknown.

div.head: Genre
div.p: Composite verse and prose illustrated travelogue. As proposed in Composition and Publication, Ruskin and his father may originally have conceived the genre of the work as a travelogue solely in verse—a version represented by a manuscript now bound in MS IA, and designated in ERM as MS IA, g.1. The work returned to this characterization as an all‐verse travelogue, when selections were excerpted and revised under the title, “Fragments from a Metrical Journal” (see Title). By this time, however, the scenario of a “Metrical Journal” was imaginary, since Ruskin had developed the work into a composite genre that included prose and graphic elements, as well as poetry, in its MS IX version.

div.head: Manuscripts
div.p: MS IA, MS VII, MS VIII, MS IX, MS XI.
Facsimile and transcript by permission of Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

MS IA and MS VIII contain draft of verse and prose sections for the “Account,” and MS IX contains Ruskinʼs fair copy of the composite genre version. MS VII and MS XI include fair copy of a few sections in hands other than Ruskinʼs.

MS IA contains two distinct manuscripts related to the “Account,” designated in ERM as MS IA, g.1, and MS IA, g.2, respectively. When W. G. Collingwood was preparing Poems (1891), he was apparently aware of both of these manuscripts, although they had not yet been bound in MS IA. Among manuscripts currently extant, MS IA, g.2, is the only known source of two poems, “Passing the Alps” and “Milan Cathedral”, and Collingwood includes both of these poems in his version of the “Account.” His aquaintance with MS IA, g.1 is equally probable, since he draws on what he calls the “original” draft of the poem, “Calais,” selecting lines that exist only in this version (see “Calais” [poem], gloss to line 2).

W. G. Collingwood is inconsistent and seemingly arbitrary in his reliance on these “originals,” however. When printing what he calls the “original draft” of the poem “Andernacht” and the “first draft” of the poem “St. Goar,” his choice among variants shows that he adopted copytext from Ruskinʼs fair copies in MS IX—and not from these poemsʼ earliest extant drafts, found in MS IA, g.2 (“Andernacht” and “St. Goar”; see Poems (4o, 1891), 1: 280–83 n. 28, n. 30, and n. 32, and Poems (8o, 1891), 1: 282 n. 28, 283–85 n. 30 and n. 32). Likewise inconsistent in his approach to MS IA, g.1, he chooses arbitrarily between lines of “Calais” as originally composed in the hand of John James Ruskin and revisions in the hand of John Ruskin—and at one point, he even invents a line of his own rather than accept either authority.

The miscellaneous contents of MS IA were collected and bound under the auspices of the editors of the Library Edition, after Collingwood published Poems (1891) (see MS IA: Provenance). Cook and Wedderburn made greater use of these earlier versions of the "Account" than did Collingwood. In their editing of “Calais”, they refer to Ruskinʼs “fatherʼs copy” of this poem, ascribing the text to MS IA, g.1; and they ascribe their copytext of “St. Goar” to the manuscript MS IA, g.2. This suggests, incidentally, that MS IA had been bound by 1903.

div.head: Date of Composition
div.p: None of the manuscripts is dated by Ruskin. Presumably, he began the work no earlier than the familyʼs departure for the Continent shortly after John James Ruskinʼs 10 May 1833 birthday, and it is possible that he began it no earlier than following their return home in late September 1833. Neither of these possible termini a quo can be ruled out by the physical evidence of what is likely the earliest extant manuscript, MS IA, g.1. This manuscript, which is in the hands of both father and son, could even have been begun during the journey itself (see Composition and Publication).

If one argues a terminus a quo for MS IA, g.1, as the return home to Herne Hill, that date would be after 19 September 1833, which was the day that the family reached Boulogne, according to John Jamesʼs travel diary (Diary of John James Ruskin, 1833–46, p. 74). A few more days would have been required in order to transact business and cross the Channel at Calais.

It is likely that Ruskin carried out the bulk of the composition and fair copying (especially the composite genre version) between October 1833 and August 1834, the latest date when he could have delivered his contribution, “Fragments from a Metrical Journal”, along with a separate poem, Saltzburg (previously misdated as December 1835), to Thomas Pringle (1789–1834) the editor of Friendshipʼs Offering; and Winterʼs Wreath . . . for MDCCCXXXV for publication (see Composition and Publication). It is possible and even likely that, in order to devote his attention to these exciting commissions, Ruskin ceased steady work on his MS IX fair copy of the “Account” some months earlier than the August deadline—perhaps abandoning the fair copy in approximately May.

Strong evidence in MS VIII shows that Ruskin labored on both draft and fair copy of the “Account” in 1834, through the period when he normally prepared anniversary poetry for his fatherʼs May birthday—the poems, namely, “The Address” and “The Vintage”, along with another poem, “The Crystal Hunter”, which he mentions in a 22 February 1834 letter to his father as having been “brought to a standstill, else should be sent” (Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 280; and see MS VIII: Contents, b.2). Some very tenuous evidence exists that he extended work on the project until much later into the year, past September 1834: in the prose section of “Brussels”, Ruskinʼs description of a distant view of the city resembles features in an engraved view of the subject based on a drawing by Turner, an engraving that Ruskin could not have seen prior to its publication in September 1834 (see the gloss on Ruskinʼs description of the cathedral towers in “Part of Brussels”). However, the similarity of Ruskinʼs and Turnerʼs prospects could be coincidental, whereas the evidence for dating the draft of the prose section of “Brussels”, which is included in MS VIII, weighs heavily in favor of a date between February through May 1834.

Ruskin probably started this MS VIII draft for the “Account”—draft consisting largely of poems relating to the Alpine and Italian stages of the tour, along with prose relating to the Belgian and German stages—around the time of his 8 February 1834 birthday. This important stint of draft can therefore be dated approximately between 8 February and 10 May. The stint terminates with draft of Ruskinʼs ekphrastic and topographical poem, “Saltzburg”, which was commissioned for Friendshipʼs Offering; and Winterʼs Wreath . . . for MDCCCXXXV. According to W. G. Collingwood, the latter poem dates from 1835, so that Ruskin must have inserted its draft later on a blank page following the 1834 sequence; however, in Composition and Publication, it is argued that the draft of “Saltzburg” falls in a logical place in MS VIII, as belonging to 1834. Its placement at the point where the MS VIII “Account” draft abruptly ends suggests that the commission of “Saltzburg” for Friendshipʼs Offering distracted Ruskin from the “Account,” and he probably never returned to the project with sustained energy. No available evidence explains the timing of this commission relative to that for “Fragments from a Metrical Journal” in the same volume of Friendshipʼs Offering.

A benchmark often connected with Ruskinʼs composition of the “Account” is his acquisition of the 1830 illustrated edition of the topographical poem Italy by Samuel Rogers (1763–1855). According to his story in the autobiography, Praeterita, it was the gift of this book for Ruskinʼs 1832 birthday along with the familyʼs acquisition by subscription in April 1833 of Facsimiles of Sketches Made in Flanders and Germany by Samuel Prout (1783–1852) that prompted the Tour of 1833 (Ruskin, Works, 35: 79; and see Discussion). The Ruskins did bring home Proutʼs book in April 1833, but it is absurd to imagine that it sponsored Margaretʼs suggestion that the family “should . . . go and see some of [the wonderful places] in reality,” and that forthwith “there were two or three weeks of entirely rapturous and amazed preparation” for such a journey. As John Dixon Hunt points out, a letter by Ruskin from 21 March 1831 indicates that the Ruskins had been planning their “Switzerlandish outlandish tour to Italy” for at least two years (Ruskin, Works, 35: 79; Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 286 n. 1, 253; and Hunt, Wider Sea).

The more elusive date is when the Ruskins acquired the 1830 edition of Italy. The question is of some interest, since it is argued in Composition and Publication that Ruskinʼs “Account” underwent a development similar to that of Rogersʼs Italy—evolving from an all‐verse to a composite‐genre work. Unfortunately, the evidence is too contradictory to be able to align the familyʼs acquisition of Rogersʼs 1830 illustrated edition with Ruskinʼs reworking of the “Account.” In the autobiography, Ruskin himself admits that he has “told this story so often” about the influence of Rogerʼs illustrated edition and its revelation of Turnerʼs art, “that I begin to doubt its time.” In Praeteritaʼs typically dramatizing fashion, Ruskin declares that “the main tenor of my life” was set on 8 February 1832 by the birthday gift from his fatherʼs business partner, Henry Telford (d. 1859). “It is curiously tiresome that Mr. Telford did not himself write my name in the book, and my father, who writes in it, ‘The gift of Henry Telford, Esq.,’ still more curiously, for him, puts no date: if it was a year later [i.e., 8 February 1833], no matter” (Ruskin, Works, 35: 79). In fact, the possible range is even wider. In a non‐illustrated edition, Rogersʼs poem had been in the Ruskin household since 1828 at the latest (Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 188 n. 4). This happens to be the year when Rogers published “Part the Second” of the poem; and growing disgusted over the workʼs tepid reception, he bought out remaining copies of both that volume and “Part the First,” and destroyed them (Rogers, Italy (1828); Rogers, Italy (1823); and see Samuel Rogers [1763–1855]). Thus, even before Rogersʼs poem achieved popularity in the illustrated edition, the Ruskins could count themselves among the select number of appreciative readers of the work in its original form, and it is possible that Ruskin and his father projected a work on this unillustrated verse model prior to Ruskinʼs receiving the gift of the illustrated version.

When, then, did Ruskin first see the 1830 version? It is possible that the gift did spur the familyʼs travel plans, but earlier than Ruskin remembered, since the first mention of Continental tour occurs in the letters the family letters for 1831. His 1831 birthday predates that first mention by only a month. An alternative, surprising possibility is that Ruskin owned the illustrated edition only after the family had returned from the Continent. According to John Jamesʼs accounts, he purchased a copy of Italy in October 1833, just shortly after the September homecoming (Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 286 n. 1). Could this explain why Telfordʼs dedication is in John Jamesʼs hand? This October 1833 purchase could well have been an additional copy of the 1830 version that was already well loved by the family, and it seems unlikely that the Ruskins would have acquired this popular book so belatedly. Nonetheless, one cannot discount the possibility that Rogersʼs tutelage of the Ruskinsʼ viewing of the Alps and Italy was, during the tour itself, solely poetic and based on earlier versions of the poem, whereas the ekphrastic influence of Turner and Stothard enhanced Ruskinʼs perception at almost precisely the time when he developed an illustrated version of his own.

div.head: Date of Publication
div.p: W. G. Collingwood attributed the first published version of the “Account,” “Fragments from a Metrical Journal”, to 1835, based on its appearance in Friendshipʼs Offering; and Winterʼs Wreath . . . for MDCCCXXXV. Forgetting that annuals were always dated on their title pages for the year following the actual date of publication, because they were produced for gift‐giving during the holiday season of Christmas and New Yearʼs, Collingwood was additionally befuddled by his assumption that another poem by Ruskin in the same volume of Friendshipʼs Offering, “Saltzburg”, could have dated only from the Ruskin familyʼs visit to Salzburg during their Continental Tour of 1835. Ruskinʼs poem was based, however, not on first‐hand experience but on an engraved vedute commissioned for the “1835” volume of Friendshipʼs Offering that was released for sale in November 1834. See Collingwood, Life and Work of John Ruskin, 1:59–60; Poems (4o, 1891), 1: 280–83 n. 28, n. 30, and n. 32; Poems (8o, 1891), 1: 282 n. 28, 283–85 n. 30 and n. 32; and see Publication for dates and discussion of subsequent publications of the “Account.”

div.head: Composition and Publication
div.p: To reconstruct the composition and explain the publication history of the “Account,” one must cope with complex materials distributed throughout several distinct manuscripts. Ruskin never completed the work, and we cannot know to what extent the surviving manuscripts represent the totality of versions that he conceived at any given stage of composition. The extant manuscripts do, however, appear representative of his evolving intentions. The compositional history is presented here, first, in the form of a summary Overview; and then the history is elaborated in separate accounts of the Draft, Fair Copy, Publication histories, and the issue of Line Numbering. The analysis is supported by two tables. Table 1 lists the sequential contents of each of the manuscripts and of the published versions of the work. Table 2 lists the sequential contents and planned extension of the final manuscript version.

div.head: Overview
div.p: The evolution of the “Account,” culminated in edited publications of November 1834, 1850, 1891, and 1903. In none of these did the editors make explicit the authority for their texts. In general, however, the successive published versions may be said steadily to approach closer to realizing Ruskinʼs intentions for the latest of his manuscript versions—the composite‐genre MS IX fair copy, along with his plan, never realized, for extending and completing the work. Although earlier versions became incorporated into the MS IX version, that final, composite‐genre form was not necessarily implied in earlier versions; and those earlier versions arguably show Ruskin pursuing a distinct form of travelogue from what the work became.
Here is a summary of the stages of composition and publication, as represented by surviving manuscripts.

list.item: In the first stage of composition, as represented by two sheets later bound in MS IA, and designated in ERM as MS IA, g.1, John and John James Ruskin collaborated on an all‐verse version of the travelogue, relating the familyʼs initial stage of their journey, which took them through northern France and Belgium. The manuscript contains poems entitled “Calais”, “Cassel”, “Lille”, “Brussels”, and “The Meuse”. The father and son composed this version either during the May‐September 1833 journey itself, or following the familyʼs return home around 20 September (see Date).

In a second stage of composition, Ruskin reconceptualized and elaborated the work as a composite‐genre rather than as a solely verse travelogue. This stage is epitomized in brief by a folded sheet, MS IA, g.2, which like MS IA, g.1 was later bound in MS IA. Serving perhaps as a sample or an abstract of the fully developed composite‐genre work to come, MS IA, g.2 contains a draft of the prose section, “Calais”, along with draft of the poems, “Passing the Alps”, “Milan Cathedral,”, “Andernacht”, and “St. Goar”. Ruskin continued to develop the composite‐genre version in draft that occupies a significant portion of MS VIII (see MS VIII: Contents, section b).

The MS VIII draft includes verse, prose, and some rough drawings, supplying text for the fair copy of the composite‐genre version that Ruskin must by this time have had underway in MS IX. This draft relates mainly to the Rhine journey, the sighting and crossing of the Alps, the tour in northern Italy, and the tour of Switzerland (see Table 1 for complete contents). Near the beginning of this draft appear the prose sections for “Andernacht” and “St. Goar”, suggestively dovetailing with the corresponding poems about those places drafted in MS IA, g.2. Thus, when Ruskin took up MS VIII to continue his draft (probably around the start of February 1834), he was catching up with composition of prose sections to match with poetry about places in Belgium and Germany, which he had already composed in the MS IA “Account” manuscripts. The next prose sections to appear in the MS VIII sequence of drafts, following the prose for “Andernacht” and for “St. Goar”, are those for “The Meuse”, “Cologne”, and “Brussels”, suggesting that by this point Ruskin had fair‐copied the full composite sections of verse, prose, and drawing for “Calais,” “Cassel,” and “Lille” in MS IX. Meanwhile, mixed in with this prose draft relating to northern Europe in MS VIII, Ruskin carried forward with poetry about the Alps (see MS VIII: Contents, section b, list b.1).

In MS IX, containing the elegant and elaborate fair copy of the composite‐genre version of the “Account,” Ruskin mimicked the verse travelogues and prose landscape annuals of the 1830s, which featured steel engravings after drawings by major landscape artists, and letterpress in verse or prose by writers who specialized in on‐demand travel writing, regardless of whether these writers had personally visited the places they described (see Discussion). Ruskin organized the fair copy as composite groups, each typically consisting of a topographical poem about the place, a prose account of travel adventures, and related drawings, and each entitled according to major destinations along the course of the Ruskinsʼ journey. In the drawings, Ruskin either exactingly copied or imitated and adapted the manner of work by topographical and figure illustrators, which he knew from publications of the 1830s. His models included, most prominently, landscape vignettes by J. M. W. Turner (1775–1851) and figure vigettes by Thomas Stothard (1755–1834) for the 1830 illustrated edition of Italy by Samuel Rogers (1763–1855); and the lithographs of architectural scenes by Samuel Prout (1783–1852) for the 1833 Facsimiles of Sketches Made in Flanders and Germany. But Ruskin drew on other graphic sources, as well, or invented his own scenes.

Ruskin failed to complete the MS IX fair copy, but he outlined its planned extension in a List of Proposed Additional Contents for Account of a Tour on the Continent, which he outlined on the back endpapers of MS VIII. Several of these proposed additions are represented by poetry or prose sections that he had already drafted in MS VIII, and some illustrations proposed in the list may correspond to drawings that form a brief gallery of Alpine scenes pasted onto otherwise blank pages at the end of the MS IX fair copy. Draft writing and drawings for this proposed extension of the fair copy may have been lost, but much of the ambitious plan probably was never executed. A few other fugitive pieces of writing, probably intended for the “Account” and fair‐copied in hands other than Ruskinʼs, can be found in MS VII and MS XI.

Ruskin commenced his List of Proposed Additional Contents for Account of a Tour on the Continent with entries for Andernacht, Ehrenbreitstein, St. Goar, Heidelberg, and Schaffhausen—sections for which he had drafted—or was in process of drafting—poems and prose in MS VIII. Since this draft occurs shortly prior to and overlaps with draft of poetry for his fatherʼs 10 May 1834 birthday, Ruskin perhaps began compiling his list of proposed contents in March or April 1834. The fair copy in MS IX breaks off in the middle of the section on Heidelberg, suggesting that Ruskin ceased fair‐copying at about the same time that he stopped drafting in MS VIII and developed the projected list of contents. However, as indicated by a list for projected development of the project, Ruskin did not so much abandon the “Account” as put the work on hold—and the reason was not the distraction of a family tour following his fatherʼs birthday, but a new major project. Ruskin segued his achievement in the “Account” into an exciting commmission for the engraved gift annual, Friendshipʼs Offering. Drawing directly on the text of the “Account,” he revised the poems “Andernacht” and “St. Goar”, which were published under the collected title, “Fragments from a Metrical Journal”. Even more auspiciously, for the same volume of Friendshipʼs Offering, he drew on his self‐instruction in the materiality of illustrated travel publications of the 1830s to compose an ekphrastic, topographical poem, “Saltzburg”, based on an engraving of that title. Both the picture by the artist, William Purser (ca. 1790–1852), and the poem presumably were commissioned by the editor, Thomas Pringle (1789–1834), and were published in Friendshipʼs Offering; and Winterʼs Wreath . . . for MDCCCXXXV. Ruskinʼs new poem, as well as his revised poems for the “Fragments from a Metrical Journal”, must have been completed no later than August 1834, when Pringleʼs compilation was due to the printer in time for publication in November 1834.

In 1850, John James Ruskin and Ruskinʼs editor, W. H. Harrison, published Ehrenbreitstein in Ruskin, Poems (1850). As one reason for selecting this poem from among the unpublished verse for “Account,” the editors may have meant to repair a rift caused by the omission of this poem from “Fragments from a Metrical Journal”, since, in the MS IX fair copy of the “Account,” the poems “Andernacht,” “Ehrenbreitstein,” and “St. Goar” form a connected trio.

Almost six decades after Ruskin started the “Account,” two versions of the work were edited for publication. One version, prepared by W. G. Collingwood for Poems (1891), consisted solely of verse extracts, in keeping with the parameters of Collingwoodʼs anthology. A second version, edited by E. T. Cook and Alexander Wedderburn for the second volume (1903) of the Library Edition, used Collingwoodʼs version as a base text, but folded in Ruskinʼs complementary prose sections from MS IX along with some additional verse that Collingwood had neglected in MS VIII.

Both of these edited versions used the MS IX fair copy as main copytext, supplemented by draft from MS VIII in order to represent the full scope of the 1833 tour. Both versions also preferred Ruskinʼs revised texts of “Andernacht” and “St. Goar” as published in Friendshipʼs Offering, although printing those poemsʼ earlier versions in the notes. Cook and Wedderburnʼs version was the first to reproduce a page from MS IX exemplifying Ruskinʼs integration of text and picture. Collingwoodʼs edition reproduced sketches that Ruskin made during the actual tour (these also reprinted in the Library Edition version). Thus, the Library Edition edition version comes closest to realizing Ruskinʼs intentions for the composite‐genre version of the “Account,” considered as a reflection of illustrated travelogues of the 1830s, whereas Collingwoodʼs version seems constructed as a biographical souvenir of the 1833 tour. Collingwood did not justify his editorial procedures for the “Account,” and he is unlikely to have derived textual authority for an all‐verse version from MS IA, g.1, which he appears not to have known (see gloss, line 2, “Calais”). In light of Ruskinʼs dismissive remarks about the “Account” in chapter 4 (1885) of the autobiography, Praeterita, it is unlikely that the now elderly Ruskin contributed to Collingwoodʼs editing, except by indirectly encouraging the biographical approach that underpins Collingwoodʼs procedure—and even in this respect, the editor elaborated his own story about the Ruskinsʼ 1833 Continental tour, as presented in his 1894 biography, Life and Work of John Ruskin (see Ruskin, Works, 35: 81; and see Discussion).

div.p: This overview is substantiated by detailed analysis in Draft, Ruskinʼs Plans for Extension of the “Account”, Fair Copy, and Publication, and Line Numbering. For ease of reference, the analysis is supported by tables, which organize information about the contents of the respective manuscripts.

list.item: In Table 1, the columns list vertically the separate verse and prose sections and illustrations of the “Account,” as they appear sequentially in the manuscripts or parts of manuscripts containing the work. Horizontally, the columns represent a rough chronological order, from the conjecturally earliest to the latest of the manuscripts, ending with the versions of the “Account” edited for publication; however, Ruskin likely worked on more than one of these manuscripts simultaneously—especially, on the MS IX fair copy, alongside the MS VIII draft—and so the sequence of composition, section by section, cannot be recovered in very specific detail. Nonetheless, in a broad view, the table represents Ruskinʼs developing intentions. This table also provides information about Ruskinʼs system of line numbering, which he attached to the verse sections of some manuscripts, and which may provide clues about the sequence of composition.

Table 2 organizes information about the contents of the “Account” from the perspective of Ruskinʼs final version, as he partly realized his vision in the fair copy, MS IX, and as he prospectively outlined the workʼs planned completion in the List of Proposed Additional Contents for Account of a Tour on the Continent. To the right of this first vertical column, additional columns indicate where drafts or fair copies of these respective prose or verse sections or illustrations can be located in surviving manuscripts or published versions. In other words, this table provides a checklist for the location of draft, fair copy, and publication of individual sections of the “Account.” The table makes note of editorial interventions in titles.

div.head: Draft
div.p: The larger hypothesis advanced here concerning the composition of the “Account” is that Ruskin developed the work in stages, from a verse travelogue in the eighteenth‐century topographical manner—as represented by MS IA, g.1, a collaboration with John James Ruskin—to a composite‐genre, illustrated travelogue that reflected the material culture surrounding the ekphrastic and travel‐related publishing of the 1830s. In so doing, Ruskin worked toward invention of the persona, “J.R.,” who signed the culminating publication of the project, “Fragments from a Metrical Journal”, published in the fashionable literary annual, Friendshipʼs Offering; and Winterʼs Wreath. With the project of the “Account” founded in a poetic collaboration with his father, and elaborated in response to his surrounding material culture of ekphrastic and topographical publication, Ruskinʼs devising of his first literary persona represents the work of both the youth himself and his editors and literary mentors. Traces of editorial intervention can be encountered only sporadically in the manuscript record, however, and evidence about Ruskinʼs interaction with the editor, Thomas Pringle (1789–1834), is indirect.

div.head: MS IA, g.1
div.p: For a physical description of MS IA, g.1, which consists of 2 sheets, see MS IA: Contents, g. The case for this manuscript as the earliest extant surviving draft of the “Account” is based on the fact that its markup for revision (e.g., deletions, substitutions, transposition of lines) is incorporated into the MS IX fair copy, and on the assumption that this group of poems about the Ruskinsʼ first leg of their Continental journey, from Calais to Brussels and along the Meuse River, formed a logical compositional starting point for the work.

The recto of sheet 1 begins with the poem, “Calais”, entitled as such, and in the hand of John James Ruskin. On the verso, John James continued with the poem, “Cassel” (untitled, and therefore identifiable as a new poem following “Calais” only by the two poemsʼ separation in the MS IX fair copy). At line 19 of “Cassel”, Johnʼs hand takes over (not Margaretʼs, whose terminal letters are typically formed differently than what prevails here). Ruskin carries the poem onto sheet 2 of the manuscript, filling recto and verso with the continuation of “Cassel”, “Lille”, “Brussels”, and “The Meuse”. Substitutions of revised lines, phrases, and words appear to be solely in Johnʼs hand, even those made to “Calais” originally in John Jamesʼs hand. Stronger proof that “Calais” and the first 18 lines of “Cassel” represent John Jamesʼs original composition, and not merely his copy of Johnʼs original verse—the latter assumed to be the case by Cook and Wedderburn (Ruskin, Works, e.g. 2: 341 n. 2)—requires additional research. It is at least evident that the father and son collaborated to some significant degree in the production of this material witness, and that the text is characteristic more of the Augustan verse travelogues that prevailed in John Jamesʼs youth than of the Byronic or Dickensian manner of travel narration that marked Johnʼs first decade as an author (see Hanson, “Ruskin in the 1830s”). In effect, this sequence of five poems stands vis‐à‐vis the composite‐genre MS IX fair copy similarly to how the earlier published texts of Samuel Rogers (1763–1855)ʼs Italy stand in relation to that workʼs repackaging in 1830 as an illustrated travelogue.

One might argue that MS IA, g.1, does not witness a distinct version of the “Account” project, one conceived as travelogue solely in verse, but rather draft that Ruskin intended to incorporate directly into the composite‐genre MS IX fair copy. That hypothesis cannot be disproven; however, evidence weighs more heavily in favor of this manuscript as representing a distinct stage of the work, in that no other draft manuscript of the “Account” consists solely of verse, and in that this manuscript physically suggests what was originally meant as a self‐standing fair copy, which was later subjected to revision. In arrangement of lines on the manuscript, John Jamesʼs large, eighteenth‐century hand required the full width of sheet 1, and John sustained his fatherʼs column in narrower scope and a smaller hand; however, on the verso of sheet 2, John stacked the lines in double columns, as if imitating a printed copy. (He inserted the final poem in the sequence, “The Meuse”, sideways in space remaining on the recto of sheet 2, rather than starting a third sheet, further substantiating the sense of the manuscript as a self‐contained entity.) The few substitutions—all apparently in Johnʼs hand, but not certainly so, especially in the case of overwriting—are largely made as strikethroughs, with insertions above or below the line, and never as in‐line revisions, suggesting that these changes formed a distinct stage of this manuscriptʼs development, following its original purpose as a fair copy. Moreover, in the margins of both sheets, Ruskin numbered the lines of the poems sequentially and continuously (1–173); that is, he did not begin his line numbering anew with each poem, suggesting that he regarded the poems as forming a sequence

div.head: MS IA, g.2
div.p: For a physical description of MS IA, g.2, see MS IA: Contents, g. This manuscript differs in size and appearance from MS IA, g.1, and it contains a prose section, “Calais”. Unlike g.1, this manuscript was rough draft from inception, with many in‐line revisions. Its place in the evolution of the “Account” appears to be a transitional one between the all‐verse and the composite‐genre versions, since it contains not only both prose and verse but also a selection of sections that seems strategic, although the exact purpose of the selection is obscure. The manuscript begins with draft of the first prose section of the MS IX fair copy (which incorporates the changes made to the draft), but the prose is followed by drafts of poems that, in topographical terms of the actual tour, skip far ahead of the familyʼs landing at Calais, as if presenting highlights of the tour.

The destinations represented by the draft poems are widely spaced but not random. The manuscriptʼs four poems form two pairs, one pair consisting of two nearly adjacent Italian destinations, “Passing the Alps” and “Milan Cathedral”, and the second pair consisting of two adjacent destinations along the Rhine, “Andernacht” and “St. Goar”. While the pairs fall in this reversed topographical order (the family actually journeyed down the Rhine to the Black Forest, and then crossed the Alps and descended to the Italian lakes and Milan), the arrangement suggests an abstract of the scope of the composite‐genre version.

Ruskin did not fair‐copy “Passing the Alps” and “Milan Cathedral” in MS IX, the fair‐copy “Account” halting after only a few lines of the prose section of “Heidelberg”. The MS IA, g.2 pair of Rhine poems do appear in the fair copy, however, the trio of poetry/prose/illustration sections on “Andernacht,” “Ehrenbreitstein,” and “St. Goar” forming Ruskinʼs final accomplishment in MS IX, before he broke off in the middle of the section on “Heidelberg” (although even that trio of sections in MS IX shows gaps for illustrations, the drawings either having been removed or having never been produced at all). In MS VIII, the draft prose sections for “Andernacht” and for “St. Goar” fall adjacent to one another, very near the beginning of the MS VIII draft sequence for the “Account”. Directly following the draft prose sections, moreover, there occur a series of draft poems relating to crossing the Alps (i.e., “Via Mala”, “Splugen”, “The Summit”, and “The Descent” (see Table 1; and MS VIII: Contents, section b, list b.1). Thus, the sequence of draft begun in MS VIII bears a near relation to the two pairs of poems drafted in MS IA, g.2.

What that relation was exactly, and what was the relative chronology of composition in MS IA, g.2, and MS VIII are problems requiring further research. It appears that MS IA, g.2, reflects a turning point in Ruskinʼs reconsideration of the genre of the “Account,” in which he drafted the prose to accompany the opening poem, “Calais” of the earlier, all‐verse version, and in which he sketched out two paired poetic representations of later cruxes in the journey, beyond the first stage of the tour in northern France and Belgium, as represented in the collaborative MS IA, g.1 manuscript. The sequence of draft taken up in MS VIII hinges on that abstract in MS IA, g.2, although the chronological relation between these two draft manuscripts and the MS IX fair copy may have been more complex, since Ruskin appears to have already begun the latter by the time he started the draft in MS VIII.

div.head: MS VIII
div.p: MS VIII is a notebook that Ruskin had used for rough copy of poetry and since 1831, and that he would continue to use for drafting imaginative work through 1836, and possibly as late as 1838. The MS VIII draft sequence for the “Account” first appears following Ruskinʼs draft of his 10 May 1833 birthday ode for John James Ruskin, “My Fatherʼs Birthday: The Month of May”. This sequence is logical, given that the family departed on the Tour of 1833 to the Continent following John Jamesʼs birthday; however, Collingwood is certainly incorrect to suggest that “the prose and verse description of . . . [the 1833 tour] was begun” in this manuscript notebook (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:264; and Poems [8o, 1891], 1:265). His statement is inadvertently not far from the mark, in that the MS VIII sequence of “Account” draft does represent the most significant development of the composite‐genre version to survive in draft, but Collingwood was not aware that this draft was preceded by earlier manuscripts—by MS IA, g.1, representing an all‐verse version of the work, and by MS IA, g.2, representing a transition to the composite‐genre version. As further analysis will show, by the time Ruskin took up MS VIII to continue his draft of the composite‐genre “Account,” he had already drafted the earlier prose sections for the “Calais,” “Cassel,” and “Lille” sections, and transferred the draft to his illustrated MS IX fair copy.

Since Ruskin did not entitle the “Account” draft in MS VIII (or anywhere else), it is not clear precisely at what point the intended draft begins. Following the birthday ode, “My Fatherʼs Birthday: The Month of May”, there occurs the verse, “Oh are there spirits, can there be”, which offers no clues in its subject matter to confirm whether Ruskin meant to connect this poem with the topographical content of the “Account.” With the next piece in the notebook, however—a prose draft that Ruskin entitled “Source of the Arveron”—he clearly had begun work belonging to the “Account” (a title that appears in Ruskinʼs List of Proposed Additional Contents for Account of a Tour on the Continent, although he never fair‐copied this prose section, which would have taken its place near the end of the MS IX fair copy). This portion of MS VIII devoted to the “Account” then remains unusually, for this notebook, homogeneous in its dedication to a single project (see MS VIII: Contents, Section b.1), only becoming mixed with other works after approximately twenty‐five items of draft for the “Account”—the draft at that point intermingling with poems related to John Jamesʼs upcoming 10 May 1834 birthday (see MS VIII: Contents, Section b.2).

By commencing the “Account” draft in MS VIII with “Source of the Arveron”, Ruskin hearkens nearly to the end of the Tour of 1833, when the family visited Chamouni, although shortly following this piece Ruskin drafts the prose sections on “Andernacht” and “St. Goar” that dovetail with the corresponding Rhine poems in MS IA, g.2. The occurrence here, so far out of topographical sequence, of Ruskinʼs reverie piece on the “Source of the Arveron” can be linked to his correspondence with the writer, James Hogg (ca. 1770–1835), which is dated 13 February 1834; and following “Source of the Arveron,” the series of poems about crossing the Alps can be connected not only with the pair of poems on that subject in MS IA, g.2 but also with his fatherʼs gift on Ruskinʼs 8 February 1834 birthday of books about the Alps—Voyages dans les Alpes (1779–96), by Horace‐Bénédict de Saussure, and Illustrations of the Passes of the Alps (1828) by William Brockedon (Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 278, 280 n. 1). This convergence of sources dates the commencement of the MS VIII “Account” draft around the middle to late February 1834.

A February date for Ruskinʼs starting the “Account” draft in MS VIII accords well with the trajectory of this writing toward a terminus ad quem among draft of poetry celebrating his fatherʼs 10 May 1834 birthday; and this date of commencement also seems well situated to account for the progress he was likely to have made on the MS IX fair copy. Although the prose sections on “Andernacht” and “St. Goar” occur near the beginning of the MS VIII draft sequence, Ruskin cannot at that time have fair‐copied so far as the Rhine portion of the work (the “Andernacht” section falling approximately two‐thirds of the way into the work as fair‐copied), since he had yet to compose at least two prose accounts belonging to the Belgian portion, as well as poetry and prose belonging to the upper Rhine. In the MS VIII “Account” draft, the prose sections describing Brussels (entitled “Part of Brussels” [part 1] and “Part of Brussels” [part 2]) and “The Meuse” come after the prose sections on “Andernacht” and “St. Goar”; and mixed among the poetry and prose describing Alpine and Italian destinations (never fair‐copied) that make up much of this draft, there is also writing on “Aix la Chapelle” “Cologne”. The Brussels and upper Rhine prose pieces fall roughly one‐fourth to one‐third of the way into the fair copy. The logical inference is that, by the middle to late February 1834, Ruskin had transferred poetry, prose, and illustration to the MS IX fair copy no farther than the section on “Brussels,” although he may by that time have completed about one‐third of the fair copy, including the sections on “Calais,” “Cassel,” and “Lille,” for which the prose sections are not extant in MS VIII. This inference would also place MS IA, g.2, with its prose section on “Calais”, no later than January 1834, if not earlier. (These conclusions assume that Ruskin worked sequentially through the MS IX fair copy.)

The MS VIII draft sequence for the “Account” contains some rough pen‐and‐ink sketches (e.g., following the draft for the prose piece, “Aix la Chapelle”), which do not correspond to any drawings in the MS IX fair copy, but which confirm that the graphic element of the composite‐genre version was now well established in Ruskinʼs working procedure.

div.head: Ruskinʼs Plans for Extension of the “Account”
div.p: On the back endpapers of MS VIII, the List of Proposed Additional Contents for Account of a Tour on the Continent starts with “Andernacht,” “Ehrenbreitstein,” and “St. Goar,” as items numbered 1–3, in a list that extends to approximately 73 parts! Thus, Ruskin must have compiled the table as a plan for the workʼs continuation, and not as an overview from start to finish. As such, we can conceive of him planning the continuation either as he began fair‐copying the sections on “Andernacht,” “Ehrenbreitstein,” and on “St. Goar,” which are the last completed sections to be fair‐copied in MS IX, or at the point where he left off fair‐copying altogether, having just started the section on “Heidelberg.” There is no way to tell whether Ruskin compiled the table all at once or developed it over time.

In the list of illustrations that forms the right‐hand column, the title of William Brockedonʼs Illustrations of the Passes of the Alps figures prominently. This book was not available to Ruskin prior to his fifteenth birthday, 22 February 1834 (see Draft: MS VIII). Other proposed drawings are keyed to illustrations in Samuel Proutʼs Facsimiles of Sketches Made in Flanders and Germany and to Samuel Rogersʼs Italy, as well to drawings of “my own.”
