div.head: Fair Copy (MS IX, MS VII, MS XI)
div.p: For details about the content and layout of the composite‐genre version of the “Account” that Ruskin realized in the MS IX fair copy, see Discussion: Sources and Influences. Ruskin assembled verse and prose from his MS IA and MS VIII draft, to form topographical units describing major destinations along the familyʼs tour. Each unit typically consists of a poem in the picturesque mode, followed by a prose piece in a comic or anecdotal mode, and with the writing encased in illustrations mimicking the appearance of engravings or lithographs, which Ruskin drew on separate slips and pasted into place. He modeled the layout on the 1830 edition of the topographical poem, Italy, by Samuel Rogers, an edition illustrated by engraved vignettes after drawings primarily by J. M. W. Turner for landscapes, and by Thomas Stothard for figures, and also including minor illustrations by Samuel Prout and others. In his own illustrations, Ruskin imitates the appearance of these steel engravings, in some cases adopting Turnerʼs manner for landscapes and Stothardʼs for figures, according to his purposes in the “Account.” Ruskin also imitates Samuel Proutʼs style of architectural drawing along with the watery appearance of lithography, a new medium that he discovered in Samuel Proutʼs 1833 Facsimiles of Sketches Made in Flanders and Germany. The text is lettered in a careful copperplate‐style hand, justified left and right.

As argued in Draft: MS VIII, Ruskin started the MS IX fair copy no later than January 1834, and perhaps earlier, sometime during the final quarter of 1833—earlier, in any case, than February 1834, when he started on the draft of the “Account” in MS VIII. As he worked on that draft from February through April, leading up to his fatherʼs 10 May 1834 birthday, and possibly somewhat beyond that date, the content of the draft gradually converged with the pace of Ruskinʼs fair‐copying in MS IX. While the MS VIII draft of the “Account” contains much that he never fair‐copied, Ruskin apparently came to a point when he was almost simultaneously drafting the section of the “Account” that he was in process of fair‐copying. He had arrived at that point, when he broke off work altogether on the MS IX fair copy.

This break occurred when Ruskin had completed fair‐copying the poem, “Heidelberg”, and had started fair‐copying the first few lines of the corresponding prose section, “Heidelberg”. The draft of this prose piece occurs intermittently in the section of MS VIII that mingles draft of the “Account” with droft of birthday poems for John James (MS VIII: Contents, b.2; see the drafts, “Cont. Heidelberg” [“Heidelberg” prose, part 1], and “All has yielded to it from time immemorial” [“Heidelberg” prose, part 2]). Just so, Ruskinʼs draft of the poem, “Heidelberg”, the last of the completed fair‐copied texts in MS IX, occurs intermittently toward the end of the section of of MS VIII that is devoted solely to draft of the “Account” (i.e., preceding the section that mingles draft of the “Account” with poetry in the making for John Jamesʼs birthday, MS VIII: Contents, b.1; see the drafts, “Smiling from those bright rays kiss” [“Heidelberg” poem, part 1], and “Continuation Heidelberg” [“Heidelberg” poem, part 2]. In this same section of MS VIII, Contents, b.1, Ruskin was also composing the poem, “Ehrenbreitstein”, along with the poem, “Heidelberg”, indicating that at that point he was readying materials for fair‐copying the trio of sections that precede the “Heidelberg“ section—“Andernacht,” “Ehrenbreitstein,” and “St. Goar.”

The cause of Ruskinʼs abruptly ceasing fair‐copying in MS IX is readily evident in the MS VIII draft of the “Account”, in which MS VIII: Contents, b.2 runs up against draft for “Saltzburg”. Ruskin did not so much abandon the “Account” as segue the project into his first professional publications, the poems for Friendshipʼs Offering.

Several blank spaces in the manuscript mark places for drawings, and one cannot determine the difference between a gap where a drawing has gone missing and one that never held anything. In 1885, commenting on the manuscript in Praeterita, Ruskin said both reasons were accountable (Ruskin, Works, 35:81). Moreover, there appears no way of knowing whether more drawings were lost (or restored) between 1885 and 1903, when Cook and Wedderburn described the manuscript for the Library Edition.

Folowing the recto (48r) containing the prose fragment for “Heidelberg”, no more text appears for the MS IX fair copy, but on the following 7 rectos (49r–55r) are pasted the 8 drawings described in Ruskin, Works, 2:364 n. 1. All of these drawings depict mountain scenes. The blank versos facing each of these 7 pages would not have been adequate to contain verse and/or prose of the length exhibited in earlier sections. It appears, therefore, that someone used these blank rectos following the cessation of Ruskinʼs fair copying as a space to exhibit a gallery of vignettes, without the expectation that intervening text would ever be fair‐copied, even though draft for text exists in MS VIII relating to these kinds of mountain scenes—and must have existed in the MS VIII draft sequence prior to assembling this gallery of drawings.

div.head: Publication
div.p: For a consideration of the broader editorial implications of this detailed account of the publication history of the “Account,” see Discussion: Editorial Approaches.

Friendshipʼs Offering; and Winterʼs Wreath . . . for MDCCCXXXV contains two verse publications signed “J.R.” In one, “Fragments from a Metrical Journal” (pp. 317–19), Ruskin revised poems taken directly from the “Account”; in the second, “Saltzburg” (pp. 37–38), he drew on his practice in topographical and ekphrastic verse that he gained in writing the “Account,” and on his observance of the materiality of illustrated travel publications of the 1830s that he imitated in the MS IX fair copy. Ruskin composed “Saltzburg” as an ekphrastic accompaniment to an engraved vedute of the city, based on a drawing by William Purser (ca. 1790–1852), which was printed facing the first page of Ruskinʼs poem.

As an annual, Friendshipʼs Offering; and Winterʼs Wreath . . . for MDCCCXXXV would have been published in November 1834, in time for the holiday season of Christmas and New Yearʼs, 1834–35. Friendshipʼs Offering was published by Smith, Elder, and in this year it was edited by Thomas Pringle (1789–1834). Both the firmʼs proprietors and the editor were Scots, like the Ruskins, and known to them personally. While some correspondence by Pringle exists to attest to his personal acquaintance with the Ruskins (Vigne, Thomas Pringle, 188), no correspondence by the editor or by the Ruskin family is known to comment on Johnʼs writing for Friendshipʼs Offering. As remarked in Draft: MS VIII, a draft of “Saltzburg” is extant; it terminates the section, MS VIII: Contents, b.2, in which draft of the “Account” combines with draft of poetry for John Jamesʼs 10 May 1834 birthday. No known draft reflects the revision of poetry in the “Account” to construct “Fragments from a Metrical Journal”, which was formed from the poems, “Andernacht” and “St. Goar”. The texts were revised from their form in MS IA, g.2, draft (i.e., “Andernacht” and “St. Goar”) and MS XI fair copy (i.e., “Andernacht” and “St. Goar”). (see Ruskin, Works, 2:353–54 n. 2).

W. G. Collingwood misdated the publication of “Saltzburg” as a year later, the end of 1835, rather than the end of 1834, and interpreted its draft in MS VIII as placed achronologically in the notebook, showing that Ruskin had “abandoned” the “Account” draft and taken up “poems descriptive of new Tour—that of 1835,” when the family first visited Salzburg. In fact, the draft is placed sequentially and chronologically, immediately following the abandoned draft of the “Account,” when Ruskin took up his commission to write a poem based on an engraved image of the city, not on a visit to the actual place. A logical timeline can also be worked out for the revision of “Andernacht” and “St. Goar” for “Fragments from a Metrical Journal”. As mentioned in Draft: MS VIII and in Fair Copy, in March or April 1834, when Ruskin was two‐thirds of his way into the MS IX fair copy of the “Account,” he compiled the trio of sections, “Andernacht,” “Ehrenbreitstein,” and “St. Goar.” Since this fair copy brought together the draft of prose sections from MS VIII, “Andernacht” and “St. Goar”, with drafts of their corresponding poems from MS IA, g.2, Ruskinʼs reliance on the original versions of these poems for fair‐copying suggests that he had no notion at this time of undertaking their revision for professional publication. Since that segment of fair‐copying took place approximately in March or April 1834, Ruskin may have received Pringleʼs commission to revise the poems for Friendshipʼs Offering in April or May, and set about the work of revisions (as well as the composition of “Saltzburg”) during June or July—a timetable that accords well with Pringleʼs due date, 1 August 1834, for delivering the completed volume of Friendshipʼs Offering to the printer (see Vigne, Thomas Pringle, 244). (Pringle himself died on 5 December 1834; see Thomas Pringle (1789–1834) and Vigne, Thomas Pringle, 247).

This timetable also accords well with a 10 March 1834 verse epistle by Ruskin to his father, “But this day week”, which is remarkable for not mentioning the Friendshipʼs Offering commissions. In this rhymed letter, Ruskin drops the idea of sending some observations on natural history to the editor, John Claudius Loudon (1783–1843), to be considered for publication in the Magazine of Natural History, so it seems surprising that he would have failed to add a couplet or two celebrating his submissions to another editor, Thomas Pringle (Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 285). It seems more likely that, at this time, no arrangements had as yet been made with Pringle—or that, if John James had approached the editor, John as yet knew nothing about an impending professional debut as a poet. As recently as 22 January 1834, John James had written to James Hogg for advice about cultivating Johnʼs poetic talents (pointing to the “Account” as an example), but expressing misgivings about exposing his son to the public as a prodigy. This letter—in which John James renewed contact with Hogg abruptly, and following a long hiatus in the familyʼs slight relationship with the famed Scottish writer—suggests that John James was already contemplating publication of Johnʼs poetry, but the letter also reveals the caution with which Ruskinʼs parents treated such a momentous possibility. Notably, the letter mentions no specific plans having been hatched with Pringle, who was a longtime friend of Hoggʼs (Garden, ed., Memorials of James Hogg, 273–75; see also James Hogg [1770–1835], and Discussion).

Hogg was sent a sampling of Ruskinʼs verse (possibly a selection from the “Account”), to which he responded with a critique (seconded by his childrenʼs tutor) that does not survive, but that John characterized as treating him with lenience while laying stress on the derivativeness of his verse. When John replied gratefully to Hogg on 13 February 1834, he had received an invitation to visit the Ettrick Shepherd on his farm in Scotland (which John declined), but he apparently had received no direct encouragement to publish (Garden, ed., Memorials of James Hogg, 276–77). One can only speculate whether Hogg had a hand subsequently in prompting his friends—the editor, Thomas Pringle, and the publisher, Alexander Elder—to consider Ruskin as a contributor to Friendshipʼs Offering, a publication that had benefited by Hoggʼs own contributions. (The prompting may have worked in the opposite direction, with Pringle encouraging John James to apply to Hogg for advice.) One can only speculate, further, whether Pringleʼs introduction of the prodigy to Samuel Rogers—which may have occurred at this time, but concerning which no contemporary evidence is known—had any bearing on Ruskinʼs public appearance as “J.R.” Respecting the parallel case about which we do have evidence—Johnʼs proposal to submit a nonpoetic contribution to J. C. Loudonʼs Magazine of Natural History—two important facts emerge: that Ruskin considered Loudon, another Scot, to be a “friend,” and that the boy had the confidence to propose the submission himself (Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 285; see also Samuel Rogers (1763–1855), and Discussion).

In 1850, another verse selection from the “Account” was published as “Ehrenbreitstein: Fragment from a Metrical Journal (Aetat 16)” in Ruskin, Poems (1850) (pp. 8–12), the privately published collection of Ruskinʼs poetry compiled by John James Ruskin and W. H. Harrison (ca. 1792–1878) (see Ruskin, Poems [1850]). The editorsʼ title consciously references the “Fragments from a Metrical Journal” published sixteen years earlier, and it is the only poem from the “Account” project to be included in the 1850 collection.

Perhaps the choice was an acknowledgment that, in the MS IX fair copy of the “Account,” “Ehrenbreitstein” forms a thematic bridge between “Andernacht” and “St. Goar,” a connection that was broken when only the latter two poems were selected to be published as “Fragments from a Metrical Journal” (see Discussion). The poemʼs omission from “Fragments” may have been memorable as a representative exercise in economy, paring down the huge “Account” project to its sparest unit—a thematically contrasting pair of poems, the gothic “Andernacht” and the domestic “St. Goar”—without even a bridge poem to connect them. (“Ehrenbreitstein” takes as its topic the theme of confluence, like the meeting of the Rhine River and Moselle River, overlooked by the fortress of Ehrenbreitstein.) In 1834, the omission from “Fragments” of “Ehrenbreitstein,” along with so much else, may have been felt particularly keenly, since the trio, “Andernacht,” “Ehrenbreitstein,” and “St. Goar,” were the last topographical units that Ruskin completed—a kind of crowning monument, like the fortress itself, although not meant as a conclusion (see MS VIII: Contents, section b, list b.1).

For the reader of Friendshipʼs Offering; and Winterʼs Wreath . . . for MDCCCXXXV or of Ruskin, Poems (1850), the “Metrical Journal,” from which “Fragments from a Metrical Journal” allegedly was extracted, was a fiction. It was also in part a falsehood, since Ruskinʼs travel journal had not taken a solely metrical form since the MS IA, g.1, version. The reversion to this putative form in the published titles perhaps may reflect a prejudice on the part of John James Ruskin. That prejudice remained influential as late as 1891, when W. G. Collingwood published only verse selections in the first attempt to edit the “Account” as a comprehensive tour poem. (Poems [4o, 1891], 1: 119–63, 281–83; and Poems [8o, 1891], 1:119–63, 283–85). While he was aware of the scope of Ruskinʼs composite‐genre version, and aware also of Ruskinʼs extensive work on the project dispersed among several manuscripts (he identified MS VII, MS VIII, MS IX, and MS XI, but not MS IA [see Manuscripts]), Collingwood nonetheless edited the “Account” as if it were strictly the “Metrical Journal” of the “Fragments.” He was limited by the parameters of his edition, which in turn obeyed the special status that the Ruskin, Poems (1850) had awarded to poetry among Ruskinʼs juvenilia. By the 1890s, moreover, the privately printed and distributed 1850 edition of the Poems had taken on a talismanic aura for rare book collectors, and Collingwood inevitably justified the purposes of the 1891 edition in part by appealing to the “no idle curiosity . . . that prompts the admirers of Mr. Ruskinʼs works to collect his boyish writings and to learn the story of his youth.” It was in “these poems,” it was believed, “although he thrust them aside for prose,” that Ruskin “could better put the complicated feelings, thoughts, and facts which he had to tell,” and which therefore constituted “the best introduction to his later and greater books” (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:xix, xx; and Poems [8o, 1891], 1:v, vi; and see Collecting of Modern Authors in the Late Nineteenth and Early Twentieth Centuries). In particular, Collingwood was indebted to the collector, Thomas J. Wise (1859–1937), of whose “full account of the published poems” in the Complete Bibliography of . . . Ruskin (1889–93) Collingwood “gladly availed” himself (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:267; and Poems [8o, 1891], 1:268). Collingwood was therefore to some degree influenced by Wiseʼs manipulation of the bibliographical record in favor of juvenile poems that Wise could forge in the form of “rare” pamphlets (see Dearden, “Wise and Ruskin I”, 46–47; and Forgery and Piracy).

The tendency to think of the “Account” as a verse travelogue gained impetus from the elder Ruskin himself, who in Praeterita characterized it as “a rhymed history of the tour” and a “poetical account of our tour, in imitation of Rogersʼs Italy” (Ruskin, Works, 35:81). Collingwood quotes this characterization in his description of MS IX, thus implicitly pointing to some authority for presenting the “Account” as a verse travelogue. He realized, however, that in the manuscripts available to him, the “Account” consisted of both “prose and verse”; and if pressed, since he had no knowledge of the all‐verse version in MS IA, g.1, he would have acknowledged that Ruskinʼs own later understanding of the “Account” was tendentious: in boyhood, Ruskin “had intended this volume [the MS IX fair copy] to contain about 150 pieces of prose and poetry, and at least as many drawings! . . . I am pretty certain that . . . [when writing Praeterita, Ruskin] was not aware of the amount of material existing in rough copies at the back of his book‐shelves,” referring to MS VII, MS VIII, and MS XI (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:265; and Poems [8o, 1891], 1:267). Whether Collingwood would have included prose selections from the “Account” in the volume of prose that he projected as a companion to the 1891 Poems is unknown.

What engaged Collingwood about the “Account” was less its genre than its biographical record of the family tour. He prefaces his edition of the work with a passage from Praeterita in which Ruskin describes the family setting out on the Tour of 1833 (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:119; and Poems [8o, 1891], 1:119; and see Ruskin, Works, 35:79–80); and he was interested in the materials “existing in rough copies at the back of . . . [Ruskinʼs] book‐shelves,” because the trove afforded him verse to fill out the topographical sequence to the full extent of the familyʼs tour. Where these materials lacked titles, Collingwood provided identifying place‐names (see Title), sometimes on slender evidence, in order to situate poems in a topographical order. From the same motive, apparently, he reproduced only drawings that Ruskin made during the tour itself, instead of illustrating his edition with the phenomenal the MS IX fair copy. Collingwood reproduces “Watch‐tower at Andernach (1833),” which Ruskin drew in the manner of Prout; and “The Jungfrau from Interlachen (1833),” in the manner of a Turner vignette (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:128 opp., and 140 opp., respectively). (Despite the appearance of “The Jungfrau from Interlachen” to a vignette drawn for the MS IX fair copy, it must have been removed prior to the editing of the Library Edition, as Cook and Wedderburn do not record anything like it in their notes documenting placement of drawings, although at least one of these notes is muddled.)

For copytext, Collingwoodʼs first choice were texts of poems as fair‐copied by Ruskin in the MS IX fair copy, except for the three poems published in Ruskinʼs youth, in which cases he followed the revised, published texts. For “Andernacht” and “St. Goar,” in addition to the main copytexts drawn from “Fragments from a Metrical Journal”, he supplied the MS IX versions in notes. Even in these texts, Collingwood regularized punctuation and spelling, and of course he felt free to so in publishing texts for which only rough draft was available.

The Library Edition version of the “Account”, the first published version to convey the composite genre of the MS IX fair copy, was edited by E. T. Cook and Alexander Wedderburn for the second volume (1903) of the Library Edition (Ruskin, Works, 2:340–87). The editors adopted Collingwoodʼs framework of poetry, but inserted the corresponding prose sections—like their predecessor, supplementing Ruskinʼs fair copy with additional sections found in the MS VIII sequence of draft as well as with a prose passage (“Chamouni”) from MS VII.

The editors described Ruskinʼs illustrations in footnotes, and for reproduction they selected one page from the MS IX fair copy, which shows Ruskinʼs vignette copied from Turner to head the first page of the poem, “Ehrenbreitstein” (Ruskin, Works, 2:356 opp.). They also carried over the two plates from Collingwoodʼs edition that sample Ruskinʼs tour sketches Ruskin, Works, 2:354 opp., 380 opp.). As in Collingwoodʼs edition, the plate illustrating “Andernach” is situated with its corresponding poem and prose. The “Jungfrau” plate, however, is placed opposite “The Alps from Schaffhausen” in Collingwoodʼs edition, and opposite “Chamouni” in the Library Edition.

In addition to these extensions meant to represent the composite genre of Ruskinʼs final version of the “Account,” the Library Editionʼs version is more complete than Collingwoodʼs in its selection of verse, supplying additional lines for “The Summit”, the entirety of “The Descent”, and occasional lines that Collingwood overlooked in other poems. Cook and Wedderburn also quoted some variant text from draft witnesses, commenting on their differences from witnesses in the MS IX fair copy, whereas Collingwood restricted himself mainly to supplying the MS IX fair copies of “Andernacht” and “St. Goar” as variants of the versions published as “Fragments from a Metrical Journal”. Even the Library Editionʼs additional variant material from draft was often cued by Collingwood having first pointed out differences in his editorial notes.

div.head: Line Numbering in the Draft (MS IA, MS VIII)
div.p: Additional information that possibly can be used to draw inferences about Ruskinʼs intended sequence of sections of the “Account” or his sequence of composition is the line numbering, which runs throughout verse portions of the work in MS IA, g.1, MS IA, g.2, and the MS VIII draft sequence. The numbering is listed in Table 1.

In the two sheets comprising MS IA, g.1, the lines of the five poems are numbered continuously, 1–173, without breaks between the separate poems. In MS IA, g.2, the line numbering begins following the prose section for “Calais”, starting with the first line of “Passing the Alps” as line no. 360, and running continuously from poem to poem, to line no. 429. Since the poems in this manuscript could never have been conceived as sequentially ordered in a topographical sense for fair copy, this instance shows that the line count was valuable to Ruskin in some way, but not necessarily in a way that can be lined up directly against the MS IX fair copy.

In the MS VIII draft sequence, the line numbering takes up with line no. 506, applied to the mysterious poem, “Oh are there spirits, can there be”; and the numbering carries relentlessly and mechanically forward through the verse draft in MS VIII: Contents, Section b. As in MS IA, g.2, the line numbering in the MS VIII draft sequence bears no relation to the topographical sequence of sections, since these are jumbled. Here, Ruskin is mechanically numbering lines of poetry, for whatever use he made of the information.

Thus, Ruskinʼs purpose in the numbering the lines of poetry is not obvious. Doubtless, he needed a count in order to estimate space needed to fair‐copy lines; however, the system would not have helped him estimate space for prose, and the presence of the numbering in MS IA, g.1 suggests that he initiated the numbering scheme before he even conceived the plan for the fair copy. Whatever its function, the mechanical quality of the numbering, along with the lack of any appearance of its having been added at a later time, tends to reinforce the evidence that Ruskin composed draft of the “Account” in a straightforward sequence, as suggested by the regular, uncrowded appearance of the manuscripts—despite the helter‐skelter leaping around the map in topographical subjects.

In the MS VIII draft sequence, there may exist minor, localized confusions in sequence of composition, which are concealed by the apparently straightforward line numbering. For example, Ruskin started the prose section for Brussels on 62r, three‐quarters of the way down the page, and entitled it “Part of Brussels” [part 1]. This draft extends halfway through 62v, where it stops in mid‐sentence (“. . . circumnavigating,” substituted for traversing), followed by a poem, “Oh softly blew the mounting breeze” (entitled “Chiavenna” in Poems (1891) and in the Library Edition version). Ruskin numbered the poemʼs lines 810–22, which is continuous with a previous installment of verse (lines 778–809), for a quite different poem, “Oh the morn looked bright over hill and dale” [“The Black Forest”]”). The remainder of the prose passage on Brussels, “Part of Brussels” [part 2] (taken up in mid‐line, “perambulating . . . tread on it softly”) begins at the top of the next recto, 63r, and it is completed on 63v.

One inference is that Ruskin wrapped the prose around the poem, already drafted in its place, on 62v. It is equally possible, however, that the sequence of composition was what it appears to be, but that the abrupt shifts between prose and poetry provide a clue about the process of fair‐copying (provided that Ruskin had begun work in MS IX by this point). In the fair copy of this prose passage for “Brussels”, a line of text ends with the break‐point in the draft, “circumnavigating for”—with the “for” jammed against the justified right margin. The next line resumes with “perambulating.—Oh woe to the weather” etc. One might infer, then, that Ruskin fair‐copied “Part of Brussels” [part 1] in MS IX fair copy as far as he had drafted the prose in MS VIII (62v); crossed out the last word in MS VIII draft on 62v (traversing), since he could not fit it on the line in the MS IX fair copy (hence, the tightly fitted, almost run‐together “circumnavigating, for”); then stopped fair‐copying the prose in MS IX, in order to draft the poem that falls next in MS VIII, “Oh softly blew the mounting breeze” (and numbered its lines accurately in sequence); and finally resumed drafting prose with “Part of Brussels” [part 2], but changed his mind about the next word (making it “perambulating,” rather than “traversing”).

In this case, either scenario is supported by the evidence of the line numbering and the appearance of the draft. One conclusion that might be drawn from both scenarios is that fair‐copying was as important to Ruskin as composition. Another inference is the unsettledness of his imagination, which could danced so mercurially from prose to verse, from the memory of Brussels to evoking the Black Forest.

A hazard of interpreting Ruskinʼs line numbering in MS VIII is that it can lead to ambiguity about what verse he intended for the “Account” project. Following the May 1833 birthday ode for his father, “My Fatherʼs Birthday: The Month of May”, Ruskin first applied the numbering (line no. 506) to “Oh are there spirits, can there be”, a poem that he did not fair‐copy in MS IX, and that Collingwood as well as Cook and Wedderburn hesitated to identify as part of the “Account.” Ruskin separated the poem from the preceding birthday ode by a horizontal line—a designation used throughout MS VIII to divide one work from another—but he supplied no title for the new piece in particular or for the “Account” in general, which would have helpfully signaled where the draft for the topographical work begins. The sole clue that the “Account” draft begins with this poem is its line numbering, which is not attached to the preceding 1831–33 poetry in MS VIII: Contents, Section a, but that does run throughout the “Account” draft. In the absence of evidence to the contrary, one must assume that Ruskin intended “Oh are there spirits, can there be” for the “Account,” despite the difficulty of situating the poem in the fair copy. (And one must understand the poemʼs reference to spiritual presences, rather than to visible topography, as a significant aspect of Ruskinʼs thinking about his first journey abroad—particularly the mountain scenery that may form the context of this lyric, with “Source of the Arveron” falling next in sequence, which likewise evokes spiritual presences.

This discussion is provided as a demonstration of how Ruskinʼs line numbering might be used as evidence in establishing the contents and development of the “Account.” Use of this evidence always calls for caution, since the evidence is ambiguous in itself, and Ruskin was sometimes inconsistent in how he applied the numbering. In MS VIII: Contents, b.2, he extended the numbering system from draft poetry for the “Account” into verse that clearly does not belong to the project, such as the “The Address” and other May 1834 birthday poems for John James, as well as “The Crystal Hunter” and other poems.

div.head: Editorial Approaches to the “Account”
div.p: In the broadest view, the publishing history of the “Account” up to 1903 (see ) might be viewed as a gradual recovery and conjectural reconstruction of Ruskinʼs final intentions for the “Account”—a steady editorial advance toward realizing his elaborately composite‐genre, albeit uncompleted MS IX fair‐copy version. From the publication in 1834 and 1850 by Ruskinʼs earliest editors, along with John James Ruskinʼs oversight, of “fragments” from a putative “metrical journal,” to the reconstruction in 1891 by W. G. Collingwood of a solely metrical journal that traced the full itinerary of the 1833 journey, to the restoration in 1903 by E. T. Cook and Alexander Wedderburn of prose pieces and drawings to Collingwoodʼs fuller metrical version—each step in this history might be read teleologically as advancing toward realizing Ruskinʼs final vision for the “Account,” by steadily accruing more of its parts. The Library Edition version crowns this editorial trend by attempting to represent most comprehensively not only the portion of the project that Ruskin fair‐copied and illustrated in the MS IX version but also the continuation of the project that he planned to form a greater whole in his List of Proposed Additional Contents for Account of a Tour on the Continent, and that he partly drafted in MS VII, MS VIII, and MS XI.

To see the editorial history as a steady advancement and simple expansion toward a single ideal text would imply, however, that each of Ruskinʼs editors projected the same ideal text. While all of these editors did presumably have access to sufficient evidence of Ruskinʼs largest ambitions for the project—his composite‐genre version—their respective treatments suggest conflicting views about a preferred ideal text. The question is complicated by the varying constraints of their publication venues (Friendshipʼs Offering, as an annual, was meant to anthologize only brief lyric poems or tales, whereas the Library Edition aimed at unprecedented completeness in collecting Ruskinʼs works), but this external factor does not entirely determine the editorsʼ differing ideas about how to represent the “Account” project most effectively or—what was for the earlier editors inseparable from representation of the text—their influence over Ruskinʼs developing idea of authorship.

Initially, in terms of authorial intention and audience, and therefore of perceived ideal text, Ruskin and his editors worked at cross purposes. In the study of modern manuscripts, Donald Reiman has argued for the importance of distinguishing between a manuscriptʼs status as public, private, and confidential—a distinction that depends, “not [on] its degree of [rhetorical or aesthetic] artfulness or the level of personal intimacy between the writer and its readers but the nature and extent of the writerʼs intended audience. A manuscript is private if its author intended it to be read only by one person or a specific small group of people whose identity he knew in advance; confidential if it was intended for a predefined but larger audience who may—or may not—be personally known to or interested in the author; and public only if it was written to be published or circulated for perusal by a widespread, unspecified audience, including such abstractions as the nation, the reading public, and posterity” (Reiman, The Study of Modern Manuscripts, 65). In the case of the “Account,” Ruskinʼs audience was private, in that he expected his productions to be read primarily by his family, but also confidential, in that his parents shared his work with friends whose identity he could not predict. For example, Ruskin could not have predicted that samples of his verse composed (probably) for the “Account” would be read by the eminent writer, James Hogg, but John James took care in his letter prefacing the sample for Hogg to establish confidentiality: “Touching my son, there are many to whom I would never name him or his pursuits; but to men of talent and of heart I find I can say many things that I dare not tell the world at large. It cannot comprehend; it has not patience, nor feeling, nor delicacy” (Garden, ed., Memorials of James Hogg, 274). In writing the “Account,” Ruskin establishes the potential confidentiality of such an audience, not by any prefatory claims on the “heart” of the reader, but by imitating public status in a document whose immediate audience is private, his family; that is, in the MS IX fair‐copy version, Ruskin imitates the materiality of illustrated travel publications of the 1830s, the steel‐engraved Annuals and Other Illustrated Books, thereby rendering this version perhaps more confidential than the MS IA, g.1, version, which was a private collaboration with his father.

In editing poems from the “Account” as “Fragments from a Metrical Journal”, Pringle replaced Ruskinʼs imitation with the actual conditions and rhetoric of a public production, while creating an illusion of the original work as less confidential than private in Reimanʼs terms. A “journal” belonging to “J.R.” seems mysteriously private in keeping with the nineteenth‐century cult of the personal, which, as Reiman remarks, led to a fashion for collecting autograph manuscripts (Reiman, The Study of Modern Manuscripts, 18–28). Thus the editor or editors—the extent of John James Ruskinʼs involvement in entitling or revising these poems is unknown—widen the supposed gap between public and private. On the one hand, in 1834 the general readers of Friendshipʼs Offering; and Winterʼs Wreath . . . for MDCCCXXXV, might have connected the title, “Fragments from a Metrical Journal”, with Byronʼs Childe Haroldʼs Pilgrimage; however, on the other hand, the text discourages a sense of the author as an “I,” having eliminated the prose pieces that affect an easy, confidentially personal tone, while revising the MS IX versions of “Andernacht” and “St. Goar” to achieve a sharper, more objective study in topographical contrast in their published versions. What Ruskin had produced as a confidential, imitatively “public” manuscript in the MS IX fair copy recedes—or seems to recede—into the privileged knowledge of the editor.

This sense of the editor as holding insiderʼs knowledge was enhanced by the publication of “Ehrenbreitstein” as “Ehrenbreitstein: Fragment from a Metrical Journal” in the privately printed and distributed Poems (1850). For many recipients of that volume, the title must have suggested merely that the editors were adding another “fragment” to the “Fragments from a Metrical Journal” that had so far been made public—if, indeed, the title meant even that much, given that the volume did not reprint the two poems that had formed the original “Fragments,” published sixteen years earlier. For readers to perceive this publication as more than just a compounding of fragments—rather, as a sophisticated reinstatement of a missing middle poem that, in Ruskinʼs MS IX fair copy, had bridged the two poems, which were later separated and published as a more severely contrasting pair in Friendshipʼs Offering—would have required a perceptive critical reading of the three fragments considered as a unit, a reading that would in turn have relied on a comprehensive knowledge of the textual history of the “Account.” Besides Ruskin himself, perhaps only John James Ruskin and W. H. Harrison possessed that privileged and knowledgable perspective. Since this edition was printed for private circulation, the editors were in a position to share their privileged knowledge with readers. Still, for many of the original recipients of the volume (as well as for the collectors who acquired copies later), “Ehrenbreitstein: Fragment from a Metrical Journal” would not have been perceived less as opening up an ideal text of the hitherto unknown portions of a “metrical journal,” than as testifying to a private and privileged story about the former omission of this “fragment.” As John James Ruskin wrote to Harrison, clarifying his intention regarding the audience of the 1850 collection, “the Book although apparently so is not intended to be anonymous in a Single Instance [i.e., of selections included in the anthology]. It is only denied the public” (Durham, 24 March 1850 [MSL 003/004/096], in Letters from John James Ruskin to W. H. Harrison, 1838–1853).

W. G. Collingwood situated himself in this tradition of the privileged editor, by virtue of his decision to restrict his 1891 edition to poetry, reserving an edition of early prose for a separate volume (see Ruskin, Poems [1850]). Now, the audience for the “Account” was again public, but inflected by the culture of rare book collecting, which created a new audience of eager and competitive consumers for rare copies of the 1850 Poems by “J.R.“ Thus, in one sense, Collingwoodʼs version maintains the tradition of allowing public access to only fragments from a private horde—so private that not even Ruskin himself, much less the collector privileged by mere cash to own the 1850 Poems, was “aware of the amount of material [for the “Account”] existing in rough copies at the back of . . . [Ruskinʼs] book‐shelves” (see Publication: 1891). In another sense, Collingwood could re‐frame the “Account” as a public work, available to an anonymous audience, since Ruskin had told its story in Praeterita. Collingwood signals this orientation by quoting long, contextualizing passages from the autobiography at the head of the poem and in his notes; and his his version of the text, which expands the verse selections to cover the full scope of the 1833 tour, serves as a poetic, documentary gloss on Ruskinʼs prose autobiographical narration of the masterʼs first significant experience of Continental landscape and towns. Yet, if Collingwood relies on the autobiography to authorize his version of a public text, his all‐verse version can claim only faulty authority relative to the manuscript “material . . . at the back of . . . [Ruskinʼs] book‐shelves,” for this version is not the young Ruskinʼs composite‐genre “Account.” Ironically, the manuscript that would have supplied some authorization for such a version—the all‐verse, and perhaps more private collaboration between Ruskin and his father, MS IA, g.1—was unknown to Collingwood.

Collingwoodʼs version therefore was a step toward an ideal text of Ruskinʼs original intentions for the “Account” only in a limited sense. As if jealous even of the public dimension that he afforded the work by constructing it as a tour poem illustrative of Praeterita, Collingwood substituted a new narrative in his 1894 biography, Life and Work of John Ruskin, suggesting that Johnʼs motives in making the work were furtive and separate from his fatherʼs interests, a closely held harbinger of Ruskinʼs mature mission in Modern Painters (see Hanson, “Ruskin in the 1830s”). This conception is almost the opposite of Ruskinʼs intention in his youth, which was to imitate a public work of his own time—an imitation of Rogersʼs Italy, as acknowledged in Praeterita—and which was meant to be confidentially shared with readers who qualified as “men of talent and of heart.” Thus, Collingwoodʼs version was a step toward restoration of Ruskinʼs original youthful project only in the sense that it provided an expanded framework, which Cook and Wedderburn could dramatically fill out with the poemsʼ missing complementary prose pieces, and with (at least) one reproduction of a hand‐illustrated page, along with footnotes describing the remaining drawings and where in the work they are placed. The Library Editionʼs version is the first genuine attempt at representing Ruskinʼs work as originally conceptualized. At the same time, Cook and Wedderburn inherited the agendas of their predecessors, and they too inevitably framed the work also as supplemental material illustrating Ruskinʼs autobiography.

div.head: Itinerary and Tourism
div.p: For the itinerary and other details concerning the Ruskin familyʼs first major tour to the Continent, which inspired Ruskinʼs “Account,” see Tour of 1833. For the familyʼs earlier, and much more limited Continental tour, when Ruskin was only six years old, see Tour of 1825.

div.head: Sources and Influences
div.p: The most familiar description of the literary and artistic context surrounding both the actual journey of 1833 and Ruskinʼs composition of the “Account” is his story in the autobiography, Praeterita, in which he declares that “the main tenor of my life” was established by the gift of the 1830 illustrated edition of the topographical poem Italy by Samuel Rogers (1763–1855), with engraved vignettes after drawings by J. M. W. Turner (1775–1851), Thomas Stothard (1755–1834), Samuel Prout (1783–1852), and others (Ruskin, Works, 39:79; and see Rogers, Italy [1830]).

A second influence, according to Praeterita, was the familyʼs acquisition in April 1833 of Facsimiles of Sketches Made in Flanders and Germany by Samuel Prout (1783–1852): “I well remember going with my father into the shop where subscribers entered their names, and being referred to the specimen print, the turreted window over Moselle, at Coblentz. We got the book home to Herne Hill before the time of our usual annual tour” (Ruskin, Works, 39:79; and see Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 286 n. 1). This work, which was indeed published that spring with John James Ruskin listed among the printed list of subscribers, is credited by Ruskin, doubtless apocryphally, with having prompted the familyʼs tour spontaneously, whereas the journey must in fact have long been in planning: “as my mother watched my fatherʼs pleasure and mine in looking at the wonderful places, she said, why should we not go and see some of them in reality? My father hesitated a little, then with glittering eyes said—why not? And there were two or three weeks of entirely rapturous and amazed preparation” (Ruskin, Works, 39:79). It was likely the case, however, that Prout helped to orient the family to the north of Europe, as Rogers oriented them to the southern region of the Continent (see Itinerary and Tourism).

While these two publications of course did not hold exclusive sway over either the Ruskinsʼ tour itinerary or Ruskinʼs embodiment of their experiences in the “Account”, Rogersʼs and Proutʼs books did play an important and representative role in Ruskinʼs conceptualization of his familyʼs northern and southern destinations, and in the interplay of tourism and the materiality of travel writing and publication in the 1830s. Proutʼs Facsimiles provided a pictorial tour through Belgium and Germany, whereas Rogersʼs Italy led the reader on the more traditional Grand Tour of the South. The books contrasted also in their material representations. The Facsimiles consists of fifty lithographic prints of picturesque medieval and Renaissance architectural sites in northern Europe, and it contains no letterpress—only the place names lettered directly onto the lithographic stone, as part of the image, to identify the locales depicted. The lithographs, then a new medium in Britain, would have struck the Ruskins with their dramatically large size (22 by 15 inches) and watercolor‐like texture, as compared with the exquisite preciousness of the finely etched, steel‐engraved vignettes (2–3 inches by 3–4 inches) that illustrate Rogersʼs 1830 Italy. (A more typical size for the engraved area of steel‐engraved book illustration was 7 by 5 inches [Hunnisett, Steel‐Engraved Book Illustration in England, 35].) Rogersʼs Italy was also a more traditional work, despite its up‐to‐date reliance on the new technologies of steel engraving and mass production that sponsored the boom in Annuals and Other Illustrated Books. Rogersʼs verse and taste were late‐eighteenth‐century in manner, and his Italy could not compete in popularity with Lord Byronʼs fourth part of Childe Haroldʼs Pilgrimage, which is set in Venice. Rogersʼs poem gained popular acclaim solely by means of the 1830 editionʼs graphic enhancements (see Samuel Rogers (1763–1855)).

Ruskinʼs “Account” underwent a development parallel to that of Rogersʼs work, from a travelogue written solely in verse and in an eighteenth‐century manner of topographical poetry, to an illustrated composite‐genre travel narrative typical of the steel‐engraved landscape annuals of the 1830s (see Composition and Publication). As remarked above, there is some ambiguity concerning when the Ruskin family acquired a copy of the 1830 illustrated edition of Italy, which they already owned in an earlier, non‐illustrated version. Regardless of when the book entered the household, however, its influence is palpable from the start of Ruskinʼs MS IX fair copy. Critics have focused too exclusively on Rogersʼs Italy as Ruskinʼs model, at the cost tracing his imitation of Proutʼs Facsimiles (see, e.g., Spear, “Ruskinʼs Italy”), but it is true that Rogersʼs book frames the foundational layout and conception of the composite‐genre “Account”. Ruskin modeled his section divisions on Rogersʼs layout, observing how text and illustration form a coherent unit. Like Rogers, he entitles his topographical sections so as to identify a landmark destination—“Calais,” “Cassel,” “Lille,” “Brussels,” “The Meuse,” “Aix la Chapelle,” “Cologne,” “Andernacht,” “Ehrenbreitstein,” “St. Goar” and “Heidelberg”—and for these section titles, he uses a lettering that imitates Rogersʼs restrained display type. (“St. Goar” and “Heidelberg” are missing their headings, owing to the unfinished state of the fair copy.) Ruskinʼs placement of illustration vis‐à‐vis text likewise imitates Rogersʼs layout, by heading the first page of each section with a landscape vignette, above the title, in order to situate the reader in a distinct place, and by closing each section with a figure vignette, as a tailpiece in order to caption some portion of the narrative.

In this arrangement of text and image, Ruskin captured a notable innovation of the 1830 illustrated edition of Italy. Rogers probably based his layout on the admired designs by William Bulmer (1757–1830) for his Shakspeare Press, particularly Bulmerʼs editions in the 1790s of English poets, with wood‐engraved vignettes by Thomas Bewick (1753–1828) set at the heads of title pages of the poems (Piggott, Turnerʼs Vignettes, 20). This elegant page layout was not possible in the mass‐produced Annuals and Other Illustrated Books, which first arose in the 1820s. In order to achieve wide distribution, these popular books relied on the durability of steel engraving, an intaglio process that clashes with relief type. In the eighteenth‐century illustrated book, Bewickʼs fine wood engravings could be set in the same frame as the type, allowing text and image to be printed together on the same page. To solve this problem, and achieve the elegant effects of Bulmerʼs designs, and yet print the books on a massive scale, Rogersʼs printers innovated a technique, which was widely remarked in reviews of the 1830 Italy, whereby precise registration allowed the sheets to be run through the press twice, once for the engraving, and once for the type (Powell, “Turnerʼs Vignettes and the Making of Rogersʼ ‘Italy’”, 3). Ruskin was attentive to this up‐to‐date innovation.

But Ruskinʼs fair‐copy version is not just an illustrated travel poem, but a composite‐genre travelogue, combining prose with verse and illustration. Although Rogersʼs Italy is subtitled A Poem, the author did include some prose—brief essays and a tale—in “Part the Second” (1828) of the work (“National Prejudices,” “Caius Cestius,” “Foreign Travel,” and “The Bag of Gold,” in Rogers, Italy (1828), 35–40, 51–52, 62–71, 107–19); and he reprinted these prose pieces and added two more tales to the 1830 edition (“Marcolini” and “Marco Griffoni,” in Rogers, Italy (1830), 85–87, 230–32). But Rogers disperses his few prose pieces irregularly, with at most a pattern of loose association with their immediately surrounding poems, whereas Ruskin constructs each of his topographical sections (with one exception), using both verse and prose. Unlike Rogers, Ruskin does not independently title his prose pieces, but subordinates them to the topographical unit, separating prose from poem with a drawing, which serves as a hinge between the writing and binds the parts into an associative, but still coherent unit. While complementing the poems, Ruskinʼs prose pieces also contrast with his rather generalized, picturesque poetic views, by bringing them down to earth with first‐person, anecdotal and comedic commentary about specific locale.

By this arrangement, Ruskin amplifies the pattern of text and illustration in the 1830 Italy, which typically consists of a landscape vignette after a drawing by Turner as a header, above a poemʼs title, and a figure vignette after a drawing by Stothard as a tailpiece. While in its present condition, the MS IX fair copy is missing many drawings (see Fair Copy), sufficient examples remain in place to confirm Ruskinʼs intentions. Compared to Italy, the “Account” not only complements each poem with a prose piece, but also supplies each poem and prose piece with its own headpiece and tailpiece—four vignettes in total for each topographical unit, the prose pieceʼs vignette serving as the hinge. Ruskin honors Rogersʼs pattern of using a landscape or cityscape as a headpiece, and a figure drawing as tailpiece, but he varies the pattern somewhat (as does Rogers) by occasionally heading a section or a prose piece with a more anecdotal, narrative vignette.

The most striking variation is the section on “Aix la Chapelle,” which begins with an imposing drawing in Proutʼs manner of the cityʼs cathedral, followed by the section heading, but which proceeds with a prose piece only, and no poem. At the end of the section, the manuscript shows a large gap, which may have been meant to be filled by a tailpiece, but which was more likely reserved for the headpiece of the following section, “Cologne” (for which the heading is lettered at the bottom of the page). The condensation of this sectionʼs parts into only a drawing and a prose piece contrasts with the expansion and elaboration that prevails in other sections. Ruskin carries the condensation into the prose commentary, which he writes in both the comic and the picturesque modes (the latter typically represented by verse in the “Account”), with the speaker first riffing on the Peace of Aix la Chapelle to mock the somnolent “peace treaties” governing the local postillions, but then rhapsodically describing with the sublimity of the cathedralʼs interior in moonlight. Finally, the speaker parodies a guidebookʼs art and artifact tour of the cathedral. Perhaps Ruskin chose “Aix la Chapelle” as an exercise in condensation in order to signify the cityʼs pivotal geographical position at the juncture of Belgium, Netherlands, and Germany, and the its distinctive, imperial status.

At the opposite end of the spectrum, Ruskin carries out the principle of elaborating Rogersʼs pattern to its fullest in the sections on “Andernacht,” “Ehrenbreitstein,” and “St. Goar.” The outer sections of the trio work as contrasts—the first, gothic in mode; and the third, domestic. Between them, “Ehrenbreitstein” plays with the topic of confluence, as the meeting point of the darkly gothic and of sunny domesticity, symbolized by the meeting point of the Rhine River and the Moselle River. The fortress of Ehrenbreitstein looms over the riversʼ juncture, depicted by Ruskin in a vignette copied after Turner. Each of the sections is planned for the fullest complement of poetry, prose, and drawings; together, the three sections traverse an elaborate yet balanced range of topographical modes.

In his drawings imitating engravings, Ruskin strives to harmonize his illustrations with text in the manner of Rogersʼs landscape illustrator, J. M. W. Turner (1775–1851), who exploited the potential of fine‐lined but durable steel engraving to allow indefinite borders of an engraving to melt into the white space of the paper, creating a world within the page (Piggott, Turnerʼs Vignettes, 14–16). Ruskinʼs drawings emphasize how such frameless, soft‐edged rectangular, square, or oval designs harmonize with his left‐ and right‐justified blocks of text to make a unity of effect. Less noticed is Ruskinʼs attention to the contrasting textures of Proutʼs lithographs, such as his copy of Proutʼs “Liege,” which concludes the section on “The Meuse.” Exacting as it is, the copy is not just mechanical, but an exploration of the anecdotal, touristic world of the travelerʼs picturesque opened up by the fluid and watercolor‐like texture of a lithograph, as compared with the fairy world of light and exotic landscape revealed by the exquisite intaglio of Turnerʼs vignettes. As the largest of Ruskinʼs drawings for the “Account,” set broadside and filling an entire page of the MS IX notebook, the “Liege” copy comments also on the scale of Proutʼs folio‐sized Facsimiles as a contrast with the miniature vignette illustrations for Rogersʼs Italy.

In Ruskinʼs liveliness of response to the material world of art production and reproduction that guided early Victorian picturesque travel, his achievement in the “Account” poses possibilities that are neglected by interpretations that insist on the narrow constraints and neuroticism of Ruskinʼs early self‐instruction in drawing. For example, Paul H. Walton sees Ruskinʼs adoption of Proutʼs “outline style” of depicting old architecture with “broken lines and dots” as one example of the youthʼs tendency “to revert to pen and ink in more factual studies of picturesque buildings and views,” owing to a misguided direction of “his earliest art activity . . . along lines strictly defined by adult standards and ideas of what was educationally desirable, so that he was not encouraged, nor did he have the time, to draw in a playful way the kinds of figure subjects in which a child imaginatively expresses and defines a conception of himself within a framework of human relationships.” As a contrast with this “crippl[ing]” of his imagination, which “had much to do with the tragedy of his personal life,” Walton points to “the happy, normal family life of a boy” like Ruskinʼs later sexual nemesis, John Everett Millais, whose youthful drawings included the kind of “subjects usually preferred by boy artists: soldiers, animals, machines, caricatures of family and friends.” As a consequence, even when a prospect of freedom opened up in Ruskinʼs youthful art teaching, such as when his first drawing master, Charles Runciman (1798–1864) challenged the boy “to imitate the free, controlled sweep of the pencil in . . . [the teacherʼs] models,” Ruskin retreated to his more formal depictions of buildings in pen and ink (Walton, Drawings of John Ruskin, 13, 7, 8, 7, 6). It is not true, however, that Ruskinʼs writing and drawings neglect subjects appropriate to “boy artists”; more importantly, Waltonʼs division of the normative from the creative, laden with convention, omits how spontaneity and invention can be prompted in surprising ways, and one of these is Ruskinʼs playfulness in manipulating the material culture surrounding a youth of the 1830s. Just as Ruskin not only amuses himself with shrinking the dimensions of the “Aix la Chapelle” section, but also insightfully considers how he can work within these self‐imposed contraints to make his prose for this section compensate for the lack of a poem by multiplying its registers of effect, so he both playfully and meaningfully shrinks the scale of his Proutesque drawing for the “Lille” section, with its topic of recession and expansion through motion—the travelers receding “Farther and farther . . . / From Cassels insulated crest” to where “Lille upon us sudden broke” in its “rich irregularity” of “form and figure fair, / . . . moving, breathing, living there” ("Lille", lines 11–12, 32, 38–40). In a contrasting strategy, he swells his Proutesque drawing of the facade of Aachen Cathedral for “Aix la Chapelle” to almost a full page, in keeping with the prose description of a monumental cathedral as “a noble, a beautiful, a sublime thing” (“Aix la Chapelle”).

Viewed in this way, the “Account” seems less the “unfinished folly” that Ruskin condemned in Praeterita (Ruskin, Works, 35:81), than a project that had yielded as much creative potential as Ruskin could teach himself, despite his compulsively listing future additions to the work on the back flyleaves of MS VIII. The project propelled him forward into active participation as the author, “J.R.,” in the material culture of ekphrastic and topographical illustrated publication.

div.head: Views of Northern Europe in Prout and Other Literary and Artistic Sources
div.p: For British travelers in the 1820s–30s, emergent developments in touristic experience were perhaps most vivid in new and less familiar routes opening up in northern Europe alongside the well‐worn path of the Grand Tour to Italy. Apart from the attraction of Waterloo Field, travel in the Pas‐de‐Calais and Flanders remained comparatively unfamiliar except as a route to be got over as quickly as possible on the way to France and Germany. While in Praeterita Ruskin exaggerates the solitary significance of Proutʼs Facsimiles (1833) in prompting the familyʼs journey, the artistʼs early importance to British perceptions of northern Europe is corroborated by the novelty of his representations of towns in northern France, Belgium, and Germany. If Byron had rushed readers down the Rhine in canto 3 (1816) of Childe Haroldʼs Pilgrimage (stanzas 46–61, in Byron, Complete Poetical Works, ed. McGann, 2:93–99), Prout enabled viewers to dwell on Illustrations of the Rhine, published 1822–26, based on an 1821 tour (see Lockett, Samuel Prout, 50–53). (Proutʼs volume documenting tours of southern Europe, Sketches Made in France, Switzerland, and Italy, was not published until 1839.) While such scenic representations grew more familiar in the later 1830s and 1840s from similar projects by T. M. Richardson (1784–1848), J. D. Harding (1797–1863), T. S. Boys (1803–74), Clarkson Stanfield (1793–1867), and Louis Haghe (1806–85), Prout was a foundational influence on artists seeking architectural picturesque subjects in these regions (Lockett, Samuel Prout, 76).

Since Prout had established his lead in depicting the market towns of the Low Countries and Germany since the 1820s, his Facsimiles of 1833 may well have served as a kind of guidebook for the Ruskins (although of course they could not take a folio volume with them). Proutʼs views would have persuaded them to adopt a more leisurely and attentive pace through these towns, on the first leg of their Continental tour. In fact, the route that the Ruskins traced through northern France and along the Rhine in Germany is strikingly similar to the actual path of Proutʼs sketching tour of 1821, although the sequence of the published lithographs in Facsimiles departs somewhat from the actual route, opening with a market scene occupying the square in front of the Hotel de Ville in Brussels (see Lockett, Samuel Prout, 50, 59). For Proutʼs itinerary and his place among other travel publications relating to northern Europe during this period, see Tour of 1833: Northern France, Belgium, and Germany.

div.head: Views of the Alps, Northern Italy, and Switzerland, in Literary and Artistic Sources
Mentors
div.p: In forming the persona J.R., Ruskin was influenced not only by literary and artistic sources, but also by living poets and artists whom he was fortunate to meet or correspond with during his conceptualization and composition of the “Account.” These contacts became especially important as Ruskin was “brought forward” as a professional contributor to Friendshipʼs Offering (see Hanson, “Ruskin in the 1830s”). Two of these men present a striking contrast with one another—Samuel Rogers (1763–1855) and James Hogg (ca. 1770–1835). Ruskin also had some contact at this time with John Claudius Loudon (1783–1843).

The personae of Hogg and Rogers each exhibited multiple and even contradictory sides, and the Ruskins must have been selective about what aspects of these public figures they hoped to cultivate in the patronage of their precocious son. Respecting Hogg, the Ruskins thought of him in his role as the Ettrick Shepherd, who was romantically imagined as having received his call to poetry when he was shepherd in Ettrick Forest in the Scottish Borders, and who still resided in georgic retirement on his farm in the Yarrow Valley. The Ruskins would have played down Hoggʼs colorful and risqué character in the “Noctes Ambrosianae” in Blackwoodʼs Edinburgh Magazine. This side of Hogg appealed to the Brontë siblings, who imitated the bravado and swagger of these dialogues in their own collaborative and competitive writing, but Ruskinʼs parents would hardly have considered such a persona as an appropriate model for Ruskinʼs solitary and decorous authorship.

When the Ruskins first met Hogg personally in 1832, he was undertaking his first visit to the metropolis of London, where was lionized by London society. Hoggʼs introduction to the Ruskins came by way of the community of expatriate Scottish literati in London who surrounded the publishing firms of John Murray and Smith, Elder. The latter, in particular, as the publisher of Friendshipʼs Offering, served as the hub for these connections: Hogg as a contributor to the annual; Thomas Pringle (1789–1834), as editor, and longtime friend of Hogg; and even Ruskinʼs cousin, Charles Thomas Richardson (1811–34), as a shopboy with the firm, who was the first to present Ruskin with a copy of Friendshipʼs Offering (probably the 1829 or 1830 volume, both of which contained contributions by Hogg).

Rogers, in sharp contrast with Hogg, was the urbane “man of taste,” whose townhouse in St. James Square was a showplace of exquisitely curated Regency neoclassicism, and the scene of his famous breakfasts in which Rogers acted the part of social arbiter of the current London artistic and literary scene. In his most positive light, Rogers might have appeared to the Ruskins as a splendid embodiment of John Jamesʼs tastes and aspirations. A former associate of Byron, and a habitué of at least the byways of fame, Rogers had earned a sound reputation for his topographical poem, Italy, which may have paled in comparison to the popular glare of Childe Haroldʼs Pilgrimage, but which was respectably and approachably neoclassical—regular in its versification, and grounded in the tradition of the Grand Tour to Italy. Rogers was also, like John James, a successful businessman, having made his fortune in banking; and even though he lavished extravagant sums on artists, engravers, and printers in order to satisfy his perfectionism in crafting editions of his poetry, Rogers recouped his huge investment in his illustrated edition of Italy and profited handsomely by its unprecedented sales. The unattractive side of Rogers was his notoriously acid wit and his worldliness at a time when middle‐class Evangelical earnestness was turning the tide on the influence of Regency “men of taste.”

The two writers also differed profoundly in taste. Rogers was so committed to his neoclassicism that Turner reined in his apocalyptic manner typical of his other works of the period in favor of a style that would harmonize with Rogersʼs restraint, by using less dramatic perspective in his vignette designs for Italy (Holcomb, “Neglected Classical Phase of Turnerʼs Art”). The artist whom Hogg most admired and hoped to secure as illustrator for his grandest gift book, a deluxe edition of The Queenʼs Wake, was John Martin (1789‐1854)—the artist who, ever far from restraining the apocalyptic, made his career by exploiting such subjects for their most histrionic theatricality and scale (All too typically for the hapless author, and despite generous subscription donations by John James Ruskin and others, Hoggʼs deluxe edition was never produced owing to disruptions in trade caused by Reform agitation in 1832; see OʼHalloran, “Illustrations to The Queenʼs Wake”, c‐civ.)

Of the two relationships, the Ruskinsʼ contact with Hogg is the best documented (see James Hogg (ca. 1770–1835)). Their apparent preference for the Ettrick Shepherdʼs advice about Ruskinʼs future as a poet, when the youth was laboring over the MS IX fair copy of the “Account”, may be no accident. Compared to Rogers, Hogg may have seemed hapless in his fortunes: his London venture ended in him foolishly mislaying his trust in an under‐financed publisher, who went bankrupt and squandered the opportunity to produce a collected edition worthy of the author, whereas Rogers boasted the means to encase his writing in increasing splendor. (In 1834, when John James wrote to Hogg about Johnʼs “promise of very considerable talent,” Rogers followed up the success of his 1830 Italy with an edition of his collected Poems, likewise illustrated by Turner, Stothard, and others, which the Athenaeum declared to be a “volume which, for true elegance and pictorial fancy, is unequalled, in an age remarkable for its love of splendid books” [Garden, ed., Memorials of James Hogg, 274; Piggott, Turnerʼs Vignettes, 39].) Nonetheless, when writing to Hogg, John James sounds pointed in addressing Hogg as a man “of talent and of heart,” as compared with “the world at large,” which lacks “comprehen[sion] . . . patience . . . feeling . . . delicacy,” suggesting that he trusted the humble Scottish “shepherd” over the urbane man of taste (Garden, ed., Memorials of James Hogg, 274).

Despite John Jamesʼs sentiments, both Rogersʼs successes and Hoggʼs disappointments were endemic to a period of transition between publishing in the age of Scott and the more entrepreneurial and innovative, yet also volatile and confusing print culture in the age of Dickens. In a time when critical discourse commonly bemoaned the decline of poetry in unpropitious circumstances (Bristow, “Introduction,” Victorian Poet, 4–5), both Rogers and Hogg appreciated how poetry could gain new life from its relation with the visual arts—a relation that was rooted in tradition reaching back to the humanist dialogue or paragone between the sister arts, yet that was also undergoing renewal and transformation by mass‐market print technologies. Both men shrewdly exploited the changes in print technology that created new venues and audiences for literature and art, such as the annuals and other illustrated books (on Hoggʼs enterprising approach to these venues during an otherwise depressed period in literary publishing, see Currie, introduction to Hogg, Contributions to Annuals and Gift‐Books, xix-xxxii; and for his appreciation of the fine arts—particularly modern painting, for its connection with literature and its accessibility to ordinary people—see Hughes, “Hogg, Art, and the Annuals”).

The sole anecdote to survive concerning Ruskinʼs audience with Rogers can be read in terms of commonalities shared by these mentors in the literary and artistic culture of the 1830s. We have no contemporary documentation of Ruskinʼs introduction to Rogers under Pringleʼs wing, other than evidence of Pringleʼs regular entrée to St. James Place (see Vigne, Thomas Pringle, 192). Ruskinʼs later story about his supposed contretemps of “congratulating . . . [Rogers] with enthusiasm on the beauty of the engravings by which his poems were illustrated,” indicating that the youth knew “more of the vignettes [in Italy] than the verses,” and the chiding of Pringle “that, in future, when . . . in the company of distinguished men, . . . [he] should listen more attentively to their conversation” evokes a bygone era that valued polite conversation and dilettantish colleccting (Ruskin, Works, 34:96, 35:93). Yet, while Ruskin fits the anecdote into what he now regarded as his fatuous beginnings as a poet, his misplaced complements to the illustrator proves him to have been a boy of his decade, who had so carefully studied the visual culture represented by Rogersʼs Italy as well as by Proutʼs Facsimiles. (While we do not know when Ruskinʼs introduction to Rogers occurred, it is a reasonable guess that Pringle secured an audience on the strength of the youthʼs precocious achievement in the MS IX fair copy of the “Account”.)

In the mentoring of J.R., perhaps the most important qualification is indicated by a word dropped in the only mention of a publication by John to survive in the family correspondence of 1834. In a verse letter to his father dated 10 March 1834, Ruskin mentions—not Pringle and Friendshipʼs Offering—but John Claudius Loudon (1783–1843), the editor of botanical, landscaping, and other natural history publications. A key is that Ruskin regarded Loudon as a “friend” of the family: “To Mr. Loudon, as a friend, / By way of some communication, / Some kind of little lucubration / On any sort of observation, / Among the Alps, you know, / On Micaslate, or any slates, / Granite, and gold, or toads and snakes, / I think that I shall make a show” (Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 285). Ruskin was alluding to his geological notes—dated March 1834, but published later that year—in Loudonʼs Magazine of Natural History, "Enquiries on the Causes of the Colour of the Water of the Rhine", and "Facts and Considerations on the Strata of Mont Blanc, and on Some Instances of Twisted Strata Observable in Switzerland". One is struck by the apparent anomaly that the one forthcoming publication to merit Ruskinʼs attention—if he was as yet apprised of his other firsts for this year, the poetry commissions for Friendshipʼs Offering—were these geological observations, and later in life Ruskin would find it convenient to stress his keenness of factual observation at the expense of his poetic effusion. Again, however, one can perceive commonalities. Loudon, like Pringle and Hogg, was a Scot—a member of the extended “family” of Scottish literati in London who surrounded the boy wonder, many of whom visited Herne Hill in the 1830s. Loudonʼs publications also depended on the thriving visual culture of illustrated books and magazines during the period, and they were perhaps not too distant from the poetry anthologies in their communal appraoch, inviting amateurs to contribute to forums such as the Magazine of Natural History and trade “lucubrations” that did not necessarily depend on professional status.
